Course Description: The first half of this course will consists of topics from measure theory, which can be considered to be a branch of mathematical analysis dealing with the foundations required to associate a notion of measure (such as volume) to subsets of a set. This study provides foundational tools for many areas of mathematics, such as Riemannian geometry, probability theory, functional analysis, dynamical systems, etc. As a specific application, we revisit probability theory using the framework of measure theory in the second half of the course.

Prerequisites.Mandatory: Real Analysis - I or Math - III or equivalent
Prerequisites.Desirable: Real Analysis - II or equivalent, Complex Analysis or equivalent

Course Outcomes.CO1: Students are able to rigorously establish the existence of Lebesgue measure
Course Outcomes.CO2: Students are able to work with Integrations
Course Outcomes.CO3: Students are able to apply measure theory to understand probability theory

Weekly Lecture Plan.Lecture Topic: Review of relevant topics from Analysis
σ-algebras of sets, monotone class theorem, σ-finite measures
Monotone & dominated conv theorems, Radon- Nikodym theorem
Distribution functions of probability measures on R
Borel-Cantelli lemma, Weak and Strong Laws of Large Numbers
Optional topic (time permitting): Ergodic theorems or Martingales

Textbook: (1) Real and complex analysis, by Walter Rudin; (2) Probability and measure, by Patrick Billingsley.
Reference Books: (1) Introduction to probability and measure, by K.R. Parthasarathy; (2) Measure Theory and Probability Theory, by Krishna Athreya and Soumendra N. Lahiri; (3) An Introduction to measure theory, by Terence Tao; (4) Probability and Stochastics, by Çınlar, Erhan
